clinical_study.brief_title: When to Perform Bladder Catheterization in Fast-track Hip and Knee Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Urinary Bladder Catheterization in Fast-track Hip and Knee Arthroplasty - What is the Optimal Bladder Volume? A Randomized, Controlled Study

brief_summary.textblock: Approximately 40 % of all patients undergoing fast-track total hip or knee arthroplasty needs intermittent bladder catheterization after surgery, as they are transient incapable of voluntary bladder emptying (postoperative urinary retention - POUR). The currently used interventional threshold for urinary bladder catheterization are a bladder volume of approximately 500 ml., but no evidence exists for this threshold. At the same time, the current knowledge suggest, that a bladder volume up to 1000 ml. for 2-4 hours are safe in humans, and as the use of urinary bladder catheterization are increasing the risk of complications, the investigators are hypothesizing that increasing the interventional threshold for urinary bladder catheterization after fast-track total hip or knee arthroplasty, will reduce the number of patients needing urinary bladder catheterization, without increasing the incidence of urological complications - including urinary tract infections.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients receiving postoperative urinary bladder catheterization
primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed from end of surgery to their first voluntary micturition, expectably within a mean period of twelve hours

secondary_outcome.time_frame: within the first 30 days after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of voiding difficulties acquired postoperatively
Number of readmissions due to urological issues (including urosepsis)

other_outcome.measure: Time from last preoperative micturition to end of surgery.
other_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be follwed from their last preoperative micturition to end of surgery. Expectably within a mean period of two hours.

other_outcome.measure: Time from last preoperative micturitions to first postoperative bladder catheterization (if relevant).
other_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be follwed from their last preoperative micturition to their first postoperative bladder catheterization (if relevant). Expectably within a mean period of six to eight hours.

other_outcome.measure: Time from last preoperative micturition to first postoperative, voluntary micturition.
other_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be follwed from their last preoperative micturition to their first postoperative, voluntary micturition. Expectably within a mean period of fourteen hours.

other_outcome.measure: Time from end of surgery to first postoperative bladder catheterization (if relevant).
other_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be follwed from end of surgery to their first postoperative bladder catheterization (if relevant). Expectably within a mean period of four to six hours.

other_outcome.measure: Time from end of surgery to first postoperative, voluntary micturition.
other_outcome.time_frame: Patient will be followed from end of surgery to their first postoperative, voluntary micturition. Expectably within a mean period of twelve hours.

arm_group.description: A bladder volume of 500 ml. or more, and incapability of voluntary micturition, is used as interventional threshold for urinary bladder catheterization.
A bladder volume of 800 ml. or more, and incapability of voluntary micturition, is used as interventional threshold for urinary bladder catheterization.

intervention.intervention_name: increased interventional threshold for urinary bladder catheterization (800 ml)
Current used interventional threshold for urinary bladder catheterization (500 ml)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- planned for elective total hip or knee arthroplasty
- given written informed consent for participation
Exclusion Criteria:
- can't co-operate to participation
- can't speak or understand danish
- preoperative use of urinary bladder catheterization
- using haemodialysis
- previous cystectomy
- need for permanent urinary bladder catheter during surgery (decided by anaesthesiologist and/or surgeon)
- Pregnant or given birth within the last 6 months
